1994: In the 1994 mid-term election, Republicans won control of both the House and the Senate for the first time since 1946. They gained almost ten seats in the Senate, claiming a slim majority of 52 to Democrats' 48. In the House, meanwhile, the Republicans gained 54 seats, bringing their total in the chamber to 230, while Democrats held 204.  Bernard Sanders of Vermont remained the sole independent in Congress. The elections saw Republicans gaining near parity in representation with Democrats in the South for the first time.
